title: What are the differences between 'post-modern' and 'contemporary' literature? - Quora

response.answer_text: A good question. It’s often said that although English has a huge number of words that are similar, it has no absolute synonyms. Although “post-modernist” and “contemporary” denote similar concepts, they are not identical - certainly not in terms of Lit Crit. First, of course, “contemporary” merely means “of the now”. This makes it quite a fluid concept. There will be contemporary literature a hundred years from now (if we are permitted to exist so long) that is very unlikely to resemble today’s “contemporary” literature. Of course, “contemporary” has a connotation that suggests a movement from the past too. Part of the problem is that many post-modernist works are contemporary. (Equally, some are not!) Post-modernism as a movement is a rejection of past certainties - hence the “modernism” part of the term is not necessarily “modern” in the way that it is used today. (Think of linguistics: “modern English” denotes the English language from the middle of the 16th Century - so Shakespeare was writing in modern English. Most of my students would have problems accepting this…) So “post-Modernism” is a movement that denies the certainties that previous writers (artists, of all kinds, of course, but the focus of this question is on literature.) accepted. From a premise that “all stories have already been told”, post-modernist literature looks at accepted narratology- and challenges it. So, for example, we have the “unreliable narrator” - a technique that that questions the very basis of how stories are told. Think of American Psycho - how we begin by believing Bateman’s narrative, but start to question his reliability - and hence the whole narrative framework. Look too at the solipsistic narrator of The French Lieutenant’s Woman - observing his characters, “deciding” what to do with them, playing with narrative causality, and even the concept of endings… (Of course, it would be quite possible to argue that earlier novels such as Wuthering Heights, and indeed Tristram Shandy, could be considered to have post-modernist features… But they of course are hardly “contemporary literature”.) So, HTH. Post-modernism seems a literary genre very suited to the age of the Uncertainty Principle, quantum mechanics and chaos theory!

In order to discuss literature, let’s start with music. Contemporary music is just that — the music that is currently being streamed on Pandora or other streaming sites. Katy Perry, Kanye West, and Taylor Swift are all producing contemporary music. Post-modern music does some things that make it both contemporary and post-modern. When, for instance, Puff Daddy (Sean Combs) sampled Sting’s Every Breath You Take on his tribute to the Notorious B. I. G., I’ll be Missing You, twenty years ago, he demonstrated a purely post-modern sentiment: pastiche aka sampling.  Post-modern anything mixes styles and is deliberately self-reflexive. In a sense, it carries a message that new art — literature, music, architecture — is composed out of the shards of what has gone before it. Postmodern literature is more interested in focusing on the fiction of fiction than on creating fiction itself. It is intentionally self-reflexive and deliberately ironic. One of my favorite authors, Robert Coover was writing post-modern short stories at the end of the 60s. In a postmodern story, the usual conventions of character, continuity, and credibility are challenged by distortions and discontinuities in both time and character portrayal.  In many respects, I think that the movie Pulp Fiction, with its ability to link competing narratives and to challenge linear time and normal expectations is a typical post-modern piece. Like post-modern literature, it employs a level of distancing through pasting together incompatible elements and stories (pastiche) by introducing elements that are borrowed from other forms and with a sense of irony that overshadows the idea of narrative.
